captions.text:
<i>It began with the forging</i>
<i>of the great rings.</i>

<i>Great miners and craftsmen</i>
<i>of the mountain halls.</i>

<i>Nine rings were gifted</i>
<i>to the race of men,</i>

<i>Was bound the strength</i>
<i>and will to govern each race.</i>

<i>In the land of mordor</i>
<i>in the fires of mount doom,</i>

<i>The dark lord sauron forged,</i>
<i>in secret, a master ring</i>

<i>And into this ring he poured</i>
<i>his cruelty, his malice,</i>

<i>One by one,</i>
<i>the free lands of middle-earth</i>

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring Official Trailer #1 - (2001) HD

comments.text:
I never read the books.. but, i have seen the lotr trilogy when it first 
came out. I was totally engrossed with the movies. Now that The Hobbit 
trilogy has come to an end, i have gone back and is currently watching, 
lotr: fellowship of the ring. idk, the opening 20 mins or so had me sad and 
happy. Just hearing Bilbo talk of his past adventures with Frodo, Gandalf 
and the little kids, it had a more deeper and kinda nostalgic feel to it, 
because we had just seen those very stories played out infront of our 
eyes.. it had me sadden at the fact that Bilbo has lived his life and now 
looking like he's bout nearly finished up with it all.. the same feeling i 
had for Tom Hanks (forgot the characters name) in the end scene in the 
Green Mile.
What im trying to say is that the Hobbit movies, has given a different 
perspective to the lotr. And im feeling like im understanding the movies a 
little more but, not just in a plot sense of the movie. But more.
Sigh
No more middle earth movies. Guess i will be reading those books ;] 
"Until our next meeting".﻿

comments.text:
OK, not trying to be annoying or ignorant, and please don't hate on me, but 
can somebody explain sufficiently what exactly make the Lord of the Rings 
books so great? I've read half the first book and I wasn't so impressed. I 
felt that the long descriptions and songs were getting kind of pointless 
after some point, and I eventually got bored and left the book. I didn't 
pick up any deep meaning and don't remember any stunning plot. The again, I 
didn't read the whole book and I wasn't reading very attentively anyway. 
Well, J.R.R. Tolkien sure uses some impressive language, but that's all I 
rememeber. Can someone enlighten me?﻿
comments.author: Ms. Chocolate Book

comments.text:
It's funny you say this, +Ms. Chocolate Book, as I felt the exact same way 
for a very, very long time. I maybe tried to read the trilogy a decade ago? 
And I felt the exact way. Now I've picked up the books again and am reading 
from the beginning. I'm half-way through Fellowship, and I completely 
agree--the first half of the book is very, very slow. Tolkien does not have 
a great sense of pacing and spends entirely too long in the Shire (in my 
humble opinion, at least). His poetry and songs can be mighty 
self-indulgent, and his descriptions, while thorough, are not entirely 
appealing, evocative or imaginative, although there are times when they're 
very well done as well.

Honestly, The Lord of The Rings is not a masterpiece in terms of prose or 
pacing--but in thematic storytelling, plot and scope. It was really the 
first of its kind in terms of the scope of the world-building. The creation 
of the languages, the introduction of the various races and their 
histories, the magnitude of the world and its geography--all from one man. 
I mean, Tolkien shaped modern fantasy as we know it. Our modern notions of 
Elves as being tall, fair, immortal beings as opposed to Santa's 
helpers--Tolkien's. Orcs being generally ugly, beastial, savage and tribal 
creatures--Tolkien's. Dwarves being great miners, warriors and having a 
sophisticated but secretive culture--Tolkien's. Hobbits, half-lings, and 
their culture--solely Tolkien. He drew loads of influence from real world 
mythology and epic poems of the past, particularly Nordic mythology and the 
epic poem of Beowulf, but so much originality came from a single man. That 
was a pretty astonishing achievement in the world of fiction at that time, 
and fantasy in particular, as everything before that was pretty much based 
in Arthurian legend and Knights of the Round Table and that ilk. Tolkien 
really did something profound and gave us a world to share and explore and 
create in, and it's earned him an unbelievable following that's well 
deserved.

But as for the books themselves, I can't say for certain how the Two Towers 
or The Return of the King will go, but after you get to Rivendell in 
Fellowship, the book picks up. Or at least that's how it felt to me. Try 
and get through all three if you can, but if not, you can say you tried. 
Maybe try again after a decade or two? It seems to be working out for me. 
Cheers.
comments.author: IrvineGray

comments.text:
A friend of mine and I talked about this.  I read the first book and it was 
probably five years or more before I read the second.  Then I read the 
third book immediately thereafter. 
The books have flaws; as a narrative of a story they can be very slow and 
stodgy.  But what inspires me about them is the awesome scope of the 
books.  They are epics, like Beowulf or the tales of Homer.  They are 
magnificent sweeps of images, emotions and moments.  I think that's why the 
movies are overall, better than the books.  The story is better off in a 
movie which is better suited to passing on feelings and images.  When I 
think of these books I am reminded of operas, fables, and old-fashioned 
Hollywood epics like "The Ten Commandments" or "Ben Hur" or "Lawrence of 
Arabia".  Especially in the case of the first two, they are an experience 
where the 'normal' movie features of character development and dialogue are 
secondary; the point is the grand scenes and archetypes drawn from legend 
and classic mythology.
And the orcs are pretty cool.
comments.author: Wil Manric

comments.text:
+Ms. Chocolate Book Yeah, I'm not really sure what mouse123426 is trying to 
prove. The books have nothing to do with the Quran, or really much to do 
with the Bible (even though Tolkien was a Christian), and certainty not the 
end times. The purpose of the story, isn't the end times, but the 
corruption of power. Though I can't actually see mouse123426's full 
comment, so I could be totally rambling here.
comments.author: Beth Mundy

comments.text:
I think it's less that it's a great novel (Even I will agree it's padded up 
the whazoo, kinda slow going and the archaic ways the characters speak can 
be a bit much to get one's head around the first time), and more that it's 
an incredibly culturally relevant one. It was one of the first great 
high-fantasy stories, and was less Tolkien trying to write a fantasy story, 
than trying to create an entire mythos: His original plan was to create a 
great epic mythos, in the style of the Greco-Roman or Norse myths, but for 
Britain. He literally created a whole world, and a very in-depth one, with 
its own cultures, languages (which were all laid out and extensively 
devised by Tolkien, he being a language professor who used to invent 
languages for fun when he was a child), creation myths, races, and all 
sorts of things the likes of which had never been seen before. Sure, 
nowadays high fantasy stories of trolls, orcs, elves and evil dark lords 
are a dime a dozen, but back in the 1940s and 50s when Tolkien was writing, 
it was still pretty rare. LOTR was pretty much the big start for 
high-fantasy as a genre of fiction.
comments.author: Michael Welsh (Femoman)

comments.text:
Thanks for the info. I really appreciate it.

comments.author: Ms. Chocolate Book

comments.text:
To understand to book, you have to read the bible and the quran. The story 
of the end of the world in those 2 books is the opposite exactly. Quran: 
the Madhi comes as a messiah from the chaos in the middle east, his 
followers carry a black flag. Bible: the anti-christ comes from the dessert 
and his followers carry a black flag. Basically its a biblical story saying 
the ancient evil is being reborn and will collect people from the entire 
world following the black flag army, the army of anti-christ, which in the 
Quran is the army of their god. The whole movie is a message to the world, 
unite because the evil is coming back. And if that's not bible influenced, 
than it's a fucking big coincidence! Only Islam enslaves their believers 
and only Islam rejects Jesus as the Son of God.

comments.author: Golikol369258

comments.text:
+Ms. Chocolate Book What makes the book the best of it's kind to ever see 
the light of the day, can be only found in it after reading the whole 
trilogy. When I have read first half of the first book I wasn't really 
satisfied by it, but later I came to conclusion why. It is because the book 
is constantly evolving, and changing. Everyone can find a part of the book 
they'll like. I don't like that part either, but I know some people who 
think that part was the best. Lord of the Ring books are composed not of 3 
separate books, but of 6 individual parts, which are composed into 
chapters. Every part and every chapter has a different characteristics, and 
they are building up to the point that you can't breathe without this book 
and characters. Years later after I first gave this book a chance, I must 
admit I have probably read this books 50 times or more by now, and I am 
still reading everyonce in a while. Go though the trilogy even once, you'll 
get exactly what do I mean. This books are like smoking (from what I've 
heard, I don't smoke) The first cig is disgusting and you won't tell how 
can people like that, then you become addicted to it, and you can't break 
free. Tolkien is a legit genius. His LotR trilogy is absolutely amazing.
comments.author: LongLive TrueFreedom
Ms. Chocolate Book

comments.text:
So, part of Tolkien's popularity is that he pretty much established the 
modern fantasy genre. Tolkien envisioned these complicated stories and 
worlds in ways no one had before. Like, before his stories the mythology of 
elves and dwarves was very different from what it is today. Personally, I 
don't think the books are well written. He has a tendency to get bogged 
down minutia that really has no bearing on the story. Also, he contradicts 
himself. He sets up the Ring to be this force that will corrupt anyone, and 
right after that introduces a character (Tom Bombadil) that isn't 
susceptible to it's powers. Now, I love Tom Bombadil, with his songs and 
woodsmanship, but he doesn't do anything for the story, and kind of 
sabotages the whole plot. Later Faramir does the same thing when he's not 
tempted by the ring. Tolkien had great use of themes, and was wonderfully 
inventive, but not an entertaining writer.
comments.author: David Huston

comments.text:
I think one of the biggest reasons it is so amazing is that the way Tolkien 
writes is so believable. There is a huge history behind everything, and the 
lore of Middle Earth is extensive and well-thought out. You can go back to 
the other books and find out that Gandalf is immensely more powerful than 
you thought, that Sauron has a much scarier boss, or that Galadriel is 
literally older than the sun. Tolkien wrote poems and songs to go with his 
books, something that is hard to do. All the characters go through 
development throughout, making friends and enemies. Also, Tolkien created 
an entire language (Elvish) as well as several versions of it. He created 
an entire world with beautiful places and ugly ones. Without Lord of the 
Rings, much of the fantasy genre as we know it now would be completely 
different. I can understand how you got bored with the books, as they are 
incredibly wordy, but trust me, it's worth it.
comments.author: Beth Mundy

comments.text:
The Hobbit didn't hold a candle to this (and the VFX here are fine!). This 
story is so much better, so much more epic! The Hobbit was plagued with to 
many attempts at humor and too many ridiculous scenes (the mountains fight 
comes to mind). No, the Hobbit should have been cut down to one 3.5 hour 
movie instead of a trilogy like TLOTRs.
